comments.body:
I like the idea of defining the range of S, P, O and G, but I think this might be _too_ restricting in some cases.

For example, JSON-LD allows [generalized RDF](https://www.w3.org/TR/json-ld11-api/#dom-jsonldoptions-producegeneralizedrdf) to be produced, which basically allows you to use blank nodes as predicates.
This change would exclude the usage of the RDFJS typings for JSON-LD tools.

There are probably even more cases where stepping outside of the RDF spec might be needed.
Can you check whether we have noUnusedGenerics disabled in the `tslint.json` for this package? If you care to work on them, there may be others in this package.
There's a `"no-unnecessary-generics": false` in the tslint. Is that the one the you refer to? I'm not getting any linting errors
Yes, if you remove that line entirely it should enable that rule.

@LaurensRietveld Any update on this one?
I'd be happy to update it myself if you can give me access to your fork.

I'm a bit confused ;). What is the problem and what is the proposed solution?

Is the problem having the `no-unnecessary-generics` flag set to false? If so, what is the recommended solution?
I think this situation results in a false-positive for this lint rule. If I see the doc for that rule, I see that it `Forbids a function to use a generic type parameter only once`. We're not using it once right? We're using if for 3 arguments and the return type.

> If so, what is the recommended solution?

I think @DanielRosenwasser just means that `no-unnecessary-generics` should be set to true by removing the line from `tslint.json`.

> We're not using it once right? We're using if for 3 arguments and the return type.

Indeed, it should be fine here. But I guess there's nothing wrong in double-checking and making the compiler settings a bit more restrictive :-)
When removing the line I get linting errors. Is that acceptable?

> I'm a bit confused ;). 

I was indeed, sorry about the confusion. This rule can indeed go. Just a simple mistake of working on the wrong branch
